rsbNotes.title: Ps 136
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 136 This psalm is an antiphonal liturgy with the memorable refrain, “his steadfast love endures forever.” A priest or soloist would chant the first part of a verse, and the congregation would respond with the refrain. Performance of the liturgy must have been powerful and moving, as the priest added example to example of God’s praise.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 136:1
rsbNotes.text: 136:1 his steadfast love endures forever. God’s mercy is His devotion to His people, to whom He is freely bound by the pledge of His own grace in His covenant. See theological note “God Is Love: Divine Goodness and Faithfulness” on next page.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 136:5
rsbNotes.text:
136:5 by understanding. God’s wisdom is associated often with the creation (Prov. 8).

made the heavens. This section meditates on God’s creation as described in Gen. 1.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 136:7
rsbNotes.text: 136:7 great lights. The sun and the moon (vv. 8, 9).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 136:10
rsbNotes.text: 136:10 the firstborn of Egypt. The tenth and most terrible plague preceding the Exodus (Ex. 11).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 136:13
rsbNotes.text: 136:13 who divided the Red Sea in two. Ex. 14; 15.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 136:19–20
rsbNotes.text: 136:19, 20 Sihon . . . Og. See 135:11 and note.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 136:23
rsbNotes.text: 136:23 remembered us. The psalm becomes personal, applying God’s salvation to the present. God continues to work as He has worked in the past to save His people from distress.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 136:24
rsbNotes.text: 136:24 our foes. The enemies are not specified, permitting the easy application of the psalm to all generations.
